election results from the broward county canvassing board  10201982  b  2 172009 filing fees for election pursuant to section 4036 of the city charter the filing fee for the office of city commission shall be five 5 percent of the annual salary of a city commissioner as well as an election assessment as provided by fs   as may be amended from time to time  2201985  b  2 172009 vacancy in candidacy for mayor or city commissioner a in the event of death withdrawal or removal from the ballot of a qualified candidate for mayor or city commission which occurs after the close of registration for candidates for mayor or city commission and if the death withdrawal or removal leaves only one 1 candidate for the office the remaining candidate shall be deemed elected and shall take office subsequent to the schedule election as provided for by applicable city laws and regulations b in the event of death withdrawal or removal from the ballot of a qualified candidate for mayor of city commission which occurs after the close of registration for candidates for the office and if said death withdrawal or removal leaves no qualified candidate for office the city shall reopen qualifying for a threeday period within thirty 30 days of the death or withdrawal the election for the office shall be held as scheduled if the supervisor of elections confirms that heshe can accommodate the new candidates on the ballot for said election  if this is not possible as determined by the supervisor of elections the city commission shall schedule a special election for the office to be held within one hundred twenty 120 days of on which the election was originally scheduled  1161991   161993   8172016 editors note of adopted nov 6 199 amended the adding provisions to be designated as ch 15  in order to keep similar material together such new provisions were added as  216 at the discretion of the editor secs 217225  reserved article iii  departments footnotes  3  cross reference public safety department  1413 et seq secs 226236  reserved article iv  boards and commissions footnotes  4  cross reference local planning agency  257 et seq division 1  generally establishment all boards groups and committees shall be established by action of the commission this action may be by way of ordinance resolution or motion whichever is appropriate under the circumstances  6131979 purpose duties and duration when establishing the boards groups and committees the commission shall set forth the purpose duties duration and procedures of the boards groups and committees  6131979 appointments a all board appointments notwithstanding any language in the enabling resolution or ordinance shall be for terms of two 2 years beginning on the third wednesday of november 2008  provided that vacancies shall occur as set forth in section 240 the terms of all board members serving as of the date of adoption of this section shall terminate on the third wednesday of november 2008  except that if a successor is not appointed then that board member shall serve until an appointment is made the board appointments of an individual commissioner shall automatically be appointed upon nomination by the appropriate commissioner  at large appointees must be approved by a majority of those members of the commission in attendance at the meeting all appointments shall serve until a successor is appointed  notwithstanding any language herein to the contrary b appointees shall be residents of the city this provision shall not preclude the city commission from waiving the residency requirement when a board it establishes requires unique experience or qualifications c appointees shall not at the time of appointment hold membership on any other city board committee or commission d all applicants for appointment to boards shall submit a fully completed application to the city clerk listing their qualifications areas of interest current residence address and telephone number applicants shall make themselves available to city commission members for personal interviews prior to appointment the city commission shall consider the knowledge relevant experience and education of the applicant in its appointments this requirement may be waived by a majority vote of the city commission e members of the board shall be eligible for reappointment  6131979   1171990   262008   172009 vacancies a upon a vacancy occurring in any board appointment the vacancy shall be filled by the commissioner who made the appointment or a majority of the city commissioners attending a meeting for at large appointments if the city commissioner who made the appointment is no longer serving hisher successor shall make the appointment or if the commission vacancy has not yet been filled as proscribed by the charter the city commission shall appoint the replacement by a majority vote of the city commissioners attending the meeting  said appointment shall be valid until the successor city commissioner is appointed or elected for all individual appointments the term of the appointee shall be deemed to end when the appointing commissioner leaves office thereby creating a vacancy to be filled as proscribed herein b appointments to the board to fill vacancies due to other than expiration of terms shall be in each instance for the unexpired remainder of the term except as set forth above c any member who is absent for more than two 2 regularly scheduled meetings in either the first or second year of his service commencing with the date of appointment shall be deemed to have vacated his position the vacancy so created shall be placed on the next city commission agenda for appointment the member who has vacated his position shall be eligible for reappointment  6131979   262008   172009 removal all individual board appointees shall serve at the pleasure of the appointing commissioner said board members may be removed at any time by the appointing commissioner appointment of a replacement at large board members shall serve at the pleasure of the city commission and said members may be removed and replaced at any time by a majority vote of the members of the commission in attendance at a commission meeting  6131979   262008 compensation the city manager shall provide appropriate staff support for the operation of any advisory board members shall receive no compensation except that if members undertake actions on behalf of the city which require them to incur costs they may apply to the city manager for reimbursement of those expenses prior to undertaking any such services it shall be within the discretion of the city manager to provide reimbursement to such member  172009 oath before entering upon his or her official duties every person appointed to an advisory board shall qualify for office by taking the oath prescribed for officeholders of the city  172009 organization  rules of procedure a annually at its first regular meeting after the city commission has appointed board members the board shall elect from its membership a chairperson and a vice chairperson each to serve until qualification of a successor elected in the year following officers of the board so elected shall be eligible to succeed themselves b the board shall adopt reasonable rules for the conduct of its business consistent with this article and other applicable law and such rules shall be published and be made available to the public c meetings shall be held at the call of the chairperson or the city manager or hisher designee at such other times as the board may determine or as otherwise provided by law special meetings shall not be held unless at least twentyfour 24 hours notice is given to each member and the city manager d members shall notify the board liaison if they are unable to attend a meeting the board liaison shall notify the alternate that hisher attendance is required if a quorum will not be present the board liaison shall notify the chairperson who may cancel the scheduled meeting e all meetings shall be open to the public f minutes shall be kept of the proceeding at each meeting which shall record the official actions taken by the board an audio tape recording of the proceedings may be available  172009 reserved division 2  parks and recreation advisory board footnotes  5  editors note  adopted aug 15 1990 did not specifically amend the   hence the provisions set hereinabove were codified as div 2  246248 at the discretion of the editor cross reference park regulations  1169 et seq created  services provided the city of parkland parks and recreation advisory board is hereby created the board shall be responsible for providing the following advisory services to the city commission 1 recommendations as to size and locations of public parks in the city 2 recommendations as to the facilities to be provided at public parks in the city 3 recommendations as to the establishment of parks and recreations systems and programs for the citizens of the city 4 recommendations on other matters involving recreational services and facilities as may be requested from time to time by the city commission  8151990   4171991 members the parks and recreation advisory board shall consist of seven 7 regular members and two 2 alternate members who shall be residents of the city each member of the city commission shall have the right to appoint one 1 member to the board and there shall be two 2 at large appointments the two 2 alternates shall be chosen at large all non at large members shall serve twoyear terms and alternates and at large members shall serve oneyear terms if the commissioners term lapses and no appointment is made for hisher position on the board a board member shall serve until hisher successor is appointed the board shall appoint a chairman and vicechairman from among its members the board shall develop and adopt rules of procedure except that in all cases the majority of the members shall constitute a quorum and no action may be taken by the board except affirmative vote of a majority of those members in attendance until such other rules of procedure are adopted roberts rules of order shall be followed at all meetings  8151990   4171991   572003   612005 compensation the city manager shall provide appropriate staff support for the operation of the parks and recreation advisory board members shall receive no compensation except that if members undertake actions on behalf of the city which require them to incur costs they may apply to the city manager for reimbursement of those expenses prior to undertaking any such services it shall be within the discretion of the city manager to provide reimbursement to such member  8151990   4171991 division 3  educational advisory board established membership the city commission hereby establishes a parkland educational advisory board the board shall consist of five 5 regular members and two 2 at large members all members of the board shall be residents of the city each member shall serve a term coextensive with the commissioner appointing that member  the two 2 at large members shall serve twoyear terms there shall be two 2 alternates serving twoyear terms the board shall also sit as a special safety committee to consider matters relating to student safety and make recommendations directly to the full board on said matters the city commission shall also appoint three 3 members who are not on the board to serve on the special safety committee  these three 3 members shall either live or work in the city  212006   2212007 meetings staff support the board shall meet as regularly as is deemed necessary  provided that the special safety committee shall meet at least twice a year the city manager shall provide appropriate staff support as deemed appropriate in his discretion the board shall operate pursuant to roberts rules of order unless it adopts other specific rules of procedure a majority of the members of the board shall constitute a quorum the board shall appoint a chairman and cochairman from among their membership  212006   2212007   validity this section shall be valid for a twoyear period unless extended by the city commission by resolution  if no extending resolution is adopted the provisions of this amendment shall lapse and be of no further force and effect  2212007 services provided the board shall make recommendations to the city commission with regard to matters relating to education in the city make recommendations to improve communications between schools and school populations to recommend projects for improving school facilities to discuss advise and if they desire to make recommendations on public school boundaries and to advise the city commission on health safety transportation and quality of life issues that affect students  212006   892006   2212007 division 4  code enforcement procedure with special magistrate footnotes  6  editors note  adopted nov 5 200 set out provisions intended for use as div 5  229237 for purposes of classification to preserve the style of this at the editors discretion these provisions have been included as div 4  2522528 intent it shall be the intent of this chapter to provide a fair and expeditious process to enforce the citys zoning and technical codes and to correct violations thereof in a manner consistent with all the procedures requirements and remedies provided for in florida statutes 2005 as amended for the purposes of this chapter the following terms phrases words and their derivations shall have the meaning given herein when not inconsistent with the context words used in the present tense include future  words in the plural number include the singular number and vice versa the word shall is always mandatory and not merely directory city means city of parkland florida city commission means the city of parkland florida commission collectively the city of parkland ordinances means any authorized agent or employee of the city whose duty it is to assure compliance with the codes manager means the city manager notice means a civil violation issued to a violator in accordance with the provisions of this chapter repeat violation means a violation of a provision of the a person whom the code enforcement special master or the code enforcement board has previously found to have violated the same provision of the five 5 years prior to the current violation special magistrate means a person appointed by the city commission to perform all duties and powers outlined in this division all references in any resolution or ordinance to special master shall be deemed to refer to the special magistrate uncorrectable violation means a violation which is irreparable or irreversible in nature and which cannot be remedied after the violation has been committed because the violation constitutes a single prohibited act rather than an ongoing condition or circumstance violator means that person or entity responsible for a violation of the 229 1152008   qualifications of code enforcement special magistrate  appointment and removal  compensation a appointments of code enforcement special magistrate shall be made by the city commission upon the recommendation of the city manager as needed on the basis of experience or interest in code enforcement b special magistrate shall be active or retired member of the florida bar with at least five 5 years of experience c appointments shall be made for a term of two 2 years by the city commission d special magistrate shall not be city employees but may be compensated at a rate to be determined by the manager subject to approval by the city commission 230 1152008   special magistrate jurisdiction and authority a the code enforcement special magistrate special magistrate shall have the jurisdiction and authority to hear and decide alleged violations of the following 1 the city zoning ordinances the land development code as it exists today and as may be amended from time to time and all ordinances relating to the development maintenance use construction or condition of real property building or structures within the city 2 all city building codes including but not limited to the florida building 3 all city fire codes and any other city ordinances to the extent permitted by law 4 in addition to the powers and authority given to the code enforcement special masters for the city pursuant to this chapter the city may in its discretion exercise any powers given to municipalities or their special magistrates by florida statutes as amended 231 1152008   enforcement procedure a except as provided in subsections b and c if a violation of the codes is found the code inspector shall notify the violator and give him or her a reasonable time to correct the violation should the violation continue beyond the time specified for correction the code inspector shall schedule a hearing the code inspector clerical staff shall schedule a hearing and written notice of such hearing shall be hand delivered or mailed as provided in florida statutes to said violator at the option of the code inspector notice may additionally be served by publication or posting as provided in florida statutes if the violation is corrected and then recurs or if the violation is not corrected by the time specified for correction by the code inspector the case may be presented to the special master even if the violation has been corrected prior to the hearing and the notice shall so state b if a repeat violation is found the code inspector shall notify the violator but is not required to give the violator a reasonable time to correct the violation the code inspector upon notifying the violator of a repeat violation shall request a hearing before the special magistrate the special magistrate clerical staff shall schedule a hearing and shall provide notice pursuant to florida statutes the case may be presented to the special magistrate even if the repeat violation has been corrected prior to the hearing and the notice shall so state if the repeat violation has been corrected the special master retains the right to schedule a hearing to determine costs and impose the payment of reasonable enforcement fees upon the repeat violator the repeat violator may choose to waive his or her rights to this hearing and pay said costs as determined by the special magistrate c if the code inspector has reason to believe a violation or the condition causing the violation presents a serious threat to the public health safety and welfare or if the violation is irreparable or irreversible in nature the code inspector shall make a reasonable effort to notify the violator and may immediately notify the special magistrate and request a hearing d if the owner of property that is subject to an enforcement proceeding before a special master transfers ownership of such property between the time the initial pleading was served and the time of the hearing such owner shall 1 disclose in writing the existence and the nature of the proceeding to the prospective transferee 2 deliver to the prospective transferee a copy of the pleadings notices and other materials relating to the code enforcement proceeding received by the transferor 3 disclose in writing to the prospective transferee that the new owner will be responsible for compliance with the applicable code and with orders issued in the code enforcement proceeding 4 file a notice with the code enforcement official of the transfer of the property with the identity and address of the new owner and copies of the disclosures made to the new owner within five 5 days after the date of the transfer a failure to make the disclosures described in paragraphs 1 2 and 3 before the transfer creates a rebuttal presumption of fraud if the property is transferred before the hearing the proceeding shall not be dismissed but the new owner shall be provided a reasonable period of time to correct the violation before the hearing is held 231 1152008   conduct of hearing a upon request of the code inspector or at such other times as may be necessary the special master shall schedule a hearing minutes shall be kept of all hearings and all hearings and proceedings shall be open to the public the local governing body shall provide clerical and administrative personnel as may be reasonably required by the special magistrate b each case before the special magistrate shall be presented by the local governing body attorney or by a member of the administrative staff of the local governing body if the local governing body prevails in prosecuting a case before the special magistrate it shall be entitled to recover all costs incurred in prosecuting the case before the special magistrate and such costs may be included in the lien authorized under 3 florida statutes c a special magistrate shall proceed to hear the cases on the agenda for that day all testimony shall be under oath and shall be recorded the special magistrate shall take testimony from the code inspector and alleged violator formal rules of evidence shall not apply but fundamental due process shall be observed and shall govern the proceedings d at the conclusion of the hearing the special magistrate shall issue findings of fact based on evidence of record and conclusions of law and shall issue an order affording the proper relief consistent with powers granted herein the order may include a notice that it must be complied with by a specified date and that a fine may be imposed and under the conditions specified in 1 florida statutes the cost of repairs may be included along with the fine if the order is not complied with by said date a certified copy of such order may be recorded in the public records of the county and shall constitute notice to any subsequent purchasers successors in interest or assigns if the violation concerns real property and the findings therein shall be binding upon the violator and if the violation concerns real property any subsequent purchasers successors in interest or assigns if an order is recorded in the public records pursuant to this subsection and the order is complied with by the date specified in the order the special magistrate shall issue an order acknowledging compliance that it shall be recorded in the public records a hearing is not required to issue such an order acknowledging compliance 233 1152008   powers of special magistrates the special magistrate shall have the power to 1 adopt rules for the conduct of its hearings 2 subpoena alleged violators and witnesses to its hearings subpoenas may be served by the sheriff of the county or police department of the municipality 3 subpoena evidence to its hearings 4 take testimony under oath 5 issue orders having the force of law to command whatever steps are necessary to bring a violation into compliance 6 to exercise all authority as granted to special magistrates in 2 florida statutes 234 1152008   administrative fines  costs of repair  liens a a special magistrate upon notification by the code inspector that an order of the special magistrate has not been complied with by the set time or upon finding that a repeat violation has been committed may order the violator to pay a fine in an amount specified in this section for each day the violation continues past the date set by the special magistrate for compliance or in the case of a repeat violation for each day the repeat violation continues beginning with the date the repeat violation is found to have occurred by the code inspector in addition if the violation is a violation described in florida statutes 4 the special magistrate shall notify the local governing body which may make all reasonable repairs which are required to bring the property into compliance and charge the violator with the reasonable cost of the repairs along with the fine imposed pursuant to this section making such repairs does not create a continuing obligation on the part of the local governing body to make further repairs or to maintain the property and does not create any liability against the local governing body for any damages to the property if such repairs were completed in good faith if a finding of a violation or a repeat violation has been made as provided in this part a hearing shall not be necessary for issuance of the order imposing the fine if after due notice and hearing the special magistrate finds a violation to be irreparable or irreversible in nature it may order the violator to pay a fine as specified in subsection b1 b 1 a fine imposed pursuant to this section shall not exceed two hundred fifty dollars $25000 per day for a first violation and shall not exceed five hundred dollars $50000 per day for a repeat violation and in addition may include all costs of repairs pursuant to subsection a however if the special magistrate finds the violation to be irreparable or irreversible in nature it may impose a fine not to exceed five thousand dollars $500000 per violation a special magistrate may impose additional fines to cover costs incurred by the city in enforcing its codes and the costs of all repairs undertaken 2 in determining the amount of the fine if any the special magistrate shall consider the following factors a the gravity of the violation  b any actions taken by the violator to correct the violation  and c any previous violations committed by the violator c a certified copy of an order imposing a fine or a fine plus repair costs may be recorded in the public records and thereafter shall constitute a lien against the land on which the violation exists and upon any other real personal property owned by the violator upon petition to the circuit court such order shall be enforceable in the same manner as a court judgment by the sheriffs of this state including execution and levy against the personal property of the violator but such order shall not be deemed to be a court judgment except for enforcement purposes a fine imposed pursuant to this part shall continue to accrue until the violator comes into compliance or until judgment is rendered in a suit filed pursuant to this section whichever occurs first a lien arising from a fine imposed pursuant to this section runs in favor of the local governing body and the local governing body may execute a satisfaction or release of lien entered pursuant to this section after three 3 months from the filing of any such lien which remains unpaid the enforcement board may authorize the local governing body attorney to foreclose on the lien or to sue to recover a money judgment for the amount of the lien plus accrued interest no lien created pursuant to the provisions of this part may be foreclosed on real property which is a homestead under  4 art x of the state constitution the money judgment provisions of this section shall not apply to real property or personal property which is covered under  4a art x of the state constitution a code enforcement lien shall have priority over all liens except those for ad valorem taxes 235 1152008   duration of lien liens shall have the duration as provided by law 236 1152008   notices notices shall be given in compliance with fs  16212 2007 as amended 237 1152008   mitigation of code liens a any respondent against whom a fine or lien has been imposed pursuant to section 2526 and who has cured the violation as determined by the city may petition in writing in a form determined by the city the code enforcement special master for mitigation of the finelien any mitigation request shall be filed with the city clerk who shall forward it to the special master the city clerk shall schedule the matter for hearing as the earliest possible special master meeting any request shall contain the circumstances which the applicant believes justifies the mitigation of the lien and shall address the factors for mitigation as forth below the city commission shall set a fee of five hundred dollars $50000 to file any request  said fee shall be paid at the time of the request b in making a determination with regard to an application for mitigation of a finelien the code enforcement special master shall consider the following factors 1 the length of time that has elapsed since a violation was determined to exist on the property by the special master  and 2 the length of time the violation existed passed the time for compliance  and 3 the difficulty in remedying the condition which led to the code enforcement violation  and 4 whether the violation was a repeat offense  and 5 the severity of the code violation and its impact upon the public health safety and welfare and the negative effects on the aesthetics of the city or the neighboring community  and 6 costs incurred by the city in prosecuting or otherwise responding to the code violation case  and 7 the costs incurred by the applicant in remedying the violation and the quality of remedy affected  and 8 the number of existing or previous code violations found or notice of code violations issued for the property in the past five 5 years  and 9 such other equitable andor legal considerations as the committee may find are appropriate c the special master shall not consider the impact of the mitigation request on the prospective sale of the property d the code enforcement special master shall hold a hearing on the mitigation request at which the applicant may present witnesses in hisher favor and the city may present witnesses which it believes are relevant to the request further members of the public may speak on the request only evidence germane to the request and the standards set forth above shall be considered by the special master in making hisher determination e at the conclusion of the hearing the special master shall render its decision and the application in writing  9182013   252014 division 5  reserved footnotes  7  editors note  adopted oct 7 200 set out provisions intended for use as div 4 and div 5  253260 for purposes of travel policy the provisions of this section are intended to be in partial substitution of the provisions of fs any successor to such statute a payment of expenses  exceptions to state statute the city will pay the reasonable travel expenses of the city commission members officers and employees incurred in connection with authorized city travel it is the intent of the city commission to follow fs with the following exceptions relating to subsection 6 rates of per diem and subsistence allowance a1 b and d are hereby modified to the following 1 breakfast $ 600 2 lunch $ 800 3 dinner $1400 4 lodging shall be based upon the group rate as indicated in conference brochure if applicable  or based on actual costs for lodging at a singleoccupancy rate which is substantiated by paid bills therefor 5 with respect to mileage allowance for the use of the privately owned vehicles the allowance shall be based upon the existing rate established by the internal revenue service irs alternative a traveler on official city business which requires overnight lodging may request a per diem payment of one hundred dollars $10000 for lodging and meals in lieu of submitting receipts for such lodging and meals the traveler shall be reimbursed onefourth 14 of the authorized per diem rate of the travel day pursuant to fs subsection 5a b advance travel authorization and advancement of funds persons shall obtain authorization for city travel and if needed an advance of funds for use on the trip by completing a travel estimate of expenses form and obtaining approval by the department director the finance department with respect to availability of funds and the city manager the travel forms are available in the finance department no advancement of funds shall be made for persons who are accompanying an authorized travel but who are not on official city business themselves if as a matter of convenience the authorized traveler wishes the city to make travel arrangements for such persons all costs of the travel arrangements shall be paid to the city before the city proceeds with such arrangements c filing of travel expense and settlements forms at the conclusion of the trip the traveler must submit a travel expense and settlement form to the city manager this settlement shall be accompanied by receipts and other documents in support of expenses set forth thereon regardless of whether or not an advance was received this travel expense and settlement form shall be filed within forty 40 days of the travelers return if the travel expense and settlement form is not filed within forty 40 days the city shall not reimburse expenses and in the case of an undocumented advancement shall have the right to deduct the amount of such undocumented advancement from future compensation payments any difference between the amount advanced and the reasonable expenses shall either be returned to the city or reimbursed to the traveler whichever is appropriate d proof of expenses the city administration shall require proof that expenditures were actually incurred and for the authorized public purpose all expenditures shall be substantiated by receipts andor other supporting documentation if adequate proof relating to any one 1 or all of the categories is not submitted reimbursement shall not be made the travel expense and settlement forms are to be approved by the department director subjected to an audit by the finance department and submitted by the city manager for review and approval the city manager shall approve all city travel by officials and employees except for the city commissioners in advance however the city manager shall keep the commission advised of the status of the commission travel budget and yeartodate expenditures the city commission shall approve any travel expenditures which exceed budgeted amounts  411998 editors note  adopted oct 7 200 set out provisions intended for use as div 4 and div 5  253260 for purposes of derived from  adopted jan 6 1988 division 3  city attorney appointment the city attorney and assistant city attorneys shall be appointed by majority vote of the commission and shall serve at their pleasure  10111978   10201982 qualifications the city attorney and any assistant city attorney shall be a practicing attorney and a member in good standing of the florida bar  10201982 duties the city attorney shall 1 act as legal adviser to the city and its officials in relation to their official duties  2 provide written legal opinions an official matters when requested to do so by the commission mayor or city manager  3 draft and review all ordinances resolutions contracts franchises or other instruments for the city  4 represent the city in all legal actions  5 perform whatever other duties division 4  city manager footnotes  11  charter reference city manager art v  noninterference of commission with performance of officers and employees appointed by city manager  505 duties the city manager shall be responsible to the commission for the proper administration of all affairs of the city coming under the city managers jurisdiction and to that end the city manager shall 1 see that the laws ordinances and resolutions of the city are enforced and carried out 2 appoint suspend demote andor remove any employees under the city managers jurisdiction 3 exercise control direct and supervise all activities of the city government except as otherwise provided in the charter 4 attend all meetings of the commission with right to take part in the discussion but without having a vote 5 recommend to the commission for adoption such measures as the city manager may deem necessary or expedient in the interest of the city 6 keep the commission fully advised not less than quarterly as to the financial conditions and needs of the city and at the appropriate time submit to the commission for its consideration an annual budget 7 advise and consult with all officers and heads of the departments of the city relative to the affairs of such departments 8 sign all forms contracts and agreements of the city 9 keep all books records and documents used by any city official or city employee 10 perform such other duties as may be prescribed under the charter or may be required by motion direction ordinance or resolution of the commission  10201982   972005 civil emergencies a definitions the following words terms and phrases when used in this section shall have the meaning ascribed to them in this subsection except where the content clearly indicates a different meaning abandoned vehicle means any vehicle in a wrecked inoperative junked or partially dismantled condition a upon any public property of the city  b on any roadway of this city without the consent of the authority having jurisdiction thereof  or c left stored or abandoned upon the property of another without the consent of the owner of the property city manager means the city manager the acting city manager or the interim city manager for the city of parkland or any designee of the city manager given specific authority with respect to the powers set forth herein city means the city of parkland county means broward county derelict vessel means any vessel that is left stored or abandoned a in a wrecked junked or substantially dismantled condition upon any public waters of the city  or b docked or grounded at or beached upon the property of another without the consent of the owner of the property disaster means the actual occurrence or threat of widespread or severe damage injury or loss of life or property resulting from a natural or humanmade causes including but not limited to fire flood hurricane tornado icesnow storm tropical storm wind oil spill earthquake explosion water contamination utility failure hazardous materials or radiological incidents epidemic air contamination blight drought infestation hostile military action terrorist activities riots or civil disorders emergency or local emergency means any accidental natural or humanmade event including but not limited to flood conflagration hazardous materials dispersal hurricanes tornado earthquake or explosion within the limits of the city resulting in an imminent threat of death or injury of persons or the destruction of property to such an extent that extraordinary measures must be taken to protect the public health safety and welfare municipal comprehensive emergency management plan means the citys comprehensive allhazard plan emphasizing action in the four 4 areas of the emergency management cycle preparedness response recovery and mitigation the national incident management system nims is used in the plan to manage and mitigate emergencies state means state of florida weapon means a firearm of any type size or configuration  cutting instrument of any type size or configuration  tear gas gun or chemical weapon or device  electric weapon or device  or any other device or object not commonly considered a weapon but which in its use intended use or threatened use is capable of causing injury to a person eg rock bottle stick club bat etc b municipal comprehensive emergency management plan in accordance with federal state and county guidelines a municipal comprehensive emergency management plan for the city the plan shall be administered and maintained by the city manager for the purpose of the management of emergency and disaster preparedness response recovery and mitigation in accordance with current federal state and county guidelines unless otherwise designated by the city manager the public works department shall coordinate emergency management procedures all actions being subject to the ultimate direction of the city manager a copy of the plan shall be on file with the city clerk c authority to declare and extend a state of emergency  activation of disaster plans a state of local emergency shall be declared by executive order of the mayor or in hisher absence or unavailability the vicemayor if the mayor finds that an emergency as defined in fs  25234 as amended from time to time has occurred in the city or that the threat thereof is imminent all executive orders issued under this subsection shall indicate the nature of the emergency the area or areas threatened and the conditions which have brought the emergency about or which make possible its termination the executive order shall be promptly disseminated by means calculated to bring its contents to the attention of the general public  and unless the circumstances attendant upon the emergency prevent or impede such filing the order shall be filed promptly with the city clerks office the maximum period of any state of local emergency declared by the mayor shall be seven 7 days  thereafter the city commission may extend the state of local emergency for an additional period of up to thirty 30 days a majority of the commission may terminate any state of emergency declared by the mayor or city commission at any time by a vote of four 4 members of the commission d clarifying and designating powers of the city manager during emergencies and disasters a general powers the city manager has the power to invoke any or all of the following provisions during a declared state of local emergency or disaster should the city manager deem it necessary to invoke any of the following provisions a written notice will be made to the local news media for immediate dissemination to the public all said actions shall be posted at an entrance to city hall if possible 1 alcoholic beverages no person shall consume any alcoholic beverages in a public street or place which is publicly owned or in any motor vehicle driven or parked thereon which is within a duly designated restricted area 2 weapons except as permitted under state law no person shall carry or possess any weapon in a public place or upon the property of another  such possession shall be prima facie evidence of an intent to violate the provisions of this section 3 restricted areas no person shall enter any area designated by the city manager or hisher designee as a restricted area unless in the performance of official duties or with written permission from the city manager or hisher designated representative or such person shall prove residence therein 4 curfews no person shall be allowed in the public or private streets or places throughout the city or in any designated sections of the same during the hours in which the city manager has declared a curfew except for the provision of designated essential services such as fire utilities police emergency medical services and hospital services including the transportation of patients utility emergency repairs and emergency calls by physicians the provisions of this subsection shall not apply to government employees in the performance of essential services or while in the service of protecting the life health safety property welfare or public peace of the community b waiver of procedures  authorized actions during a state of emergency the procedures and formalities otherwise required of the city by law may be waived by the city manager upon a finding that said action is necessary to respond to conditions created by the disaster  in such case heshe may authorize actions pertaining to the following as necessary 1 performing public work and taking whatever action is necessary to ensure the health safety and welfare of the community  2 entering into contracts  3 suspending bid provisions for a period not to exceed six 6 months from the declaration of the emergency  4 employment of permanent and temporary workers  5 utilization of volunteer workers  6 rental of equipment  7 acquisition and distribution of supplies materials and facilities  8 additional appropriation and expenditure of funds as needed for the emergency  9 implementing emergency personnel policies  10 activating andor executing the statewide mutualaid system andor interlocal agreements  11 determining a threat to public health and safety that may result from the generation of widespread debris throughout the city that such debris constitutes a hazardous environment for all modes of movement and transportation of the residents as well as emergency aid and relief services endangerment to all properties in the city an environment conducive to breeding disease and vermin and greatly increased risk of fire and that it is in the public interest to collect and remove disaster debris from all property within the city whether publiclyowned lands privatelyowned lands both public and private roads and easements including lands and roads located within any private gated community to eliminate an immediate threat of additional damage to improved property and to promote economic recovery of the community at large and the health and safety of the community at large  12 authorize the city or its contracted agent right of access to private roads and easements andor gated communities as needed by emergency vehicles such as but not limited to police fire medical care debris removal utility repairs and sanitation to alleviate immediate threats to public health and safety  13 authorize the removal of debris and wreckage resulting from a major disaster from all property whether public lands public or private roads or gated communities for a safe and sanitary living or functioning condition and to ensure proper access by public safety vehicles  14 authorize the removal of derelict vessels pursuant to current state statutes and in conjunction with the state fish and wildlife conservation commission  15 authorize the removal of abandoned vehicles pursuant to current state statutes and in conjunction with law enforcement of the city county and state  and 16 close or restrict access to public facilities in the case of any actions of the city manager as authorized in this subsection the contracts authorized shall not exceed the period of the state of local emergency or thirty 30 days whichever is less any such extension of said contracts shall only be made after a vote of the city commission all such contracts executed shall be subject to this limitation all contracts executed by the city manager pursuant to this authority shall be placed on file with the city clerk and the city manager shall report the execution of said contracts including the vendors name the services or material provided and the cost as soon as practicable to the city commission e emergency response costs any expenditure made in conjunction with emergency activities including mutual aid agreements and interlocal agreements shall be deemed conclusively to be for the direct protection and benefit of the inhabitants and property of the city f city responsibility for debris removal from private rightsofway if the property owner has executed an agreement with the city in accordance with section 2101g of the city the city access to private property for debris removal purposes the city shall be responsible for the removal of disastergenerated debris from private rightsofway adjacent to residential property when the disastergenerated debris is determined by the city manager in the city managers sole discretion in accordance with this section i to pose an immediate threat to the health safety and welfare of the public in the area ii to pose an immediate threat of significant damage to surrounding improved property within the city or iii to require removal to provide an economic benefit to the community as a whole in order to determine that there is such an immediate threat or circumstance sufficient to warrant removal of disastergenerated debris from private rightsofway adjacent to residential property within the city the city manager shall first consider the factors in this subsection and make a written finding as to whether the presence andor imminent development of any of the dangers or aggravating factors below exists 1 there is a significant likelihood that rescue vehicles will be significantly hindered from rendering emergency services to property should the debris be allowed to remain in place absent city removal  or 2 the type of disastergenerated debris is such that it may reasonably cause disease illness or sickness which could injure or adversely affect the health safety or general welfare of those residing and working in the area if it is allowed to remain  or 3 the clearing is necessary to effectuate orderly and expeditious restoration of citywide utility services including but not limited to power water sewer and telephone  or 4 the disastergenerated debris is determined to be dangerous or hazardous to persons or property  or 5 the disastergenerated debris prevents garbage collection thereby creating a public health hazard  or 6 the disastergenerated debris contains contaminants which have a reasonable likelihood of leaching into the soil andor aquifer of the city  or 7 the disastergenerated debris has a substantial negative impact in preventing or adversely affecting emergency repairs to buildings andor property  or 8 the disastergenerated debris presents a reasonable danger of being transported by wind andor water into the surrounding areas of the city and thereby increasing the cost of recovery and removal  or 9 the disastergenerated debris poses a significant likelihood of producing mold which would be injurious to public health  or 10 the presence of the disastergenerated debris significantly adversely impacts the citys recovery efforts  or 11 the disastergenerated debris significantly interferes with drainage or water runoff so as to be a significant hazard in the event of significant rainfall  or 12 the sheer volume of the disastergenerated debris is such that it is impractical and unreasonable to remove in an orderly and efficient manner absent action by the city  or 13 the type extent and nature of the disastergenerated debris is such that it would cause much greater damage if the debris was not removed immediately  or 14 if the clearance of the disastergenerated debris will aid the citys recovery operations or aid the health safety or welfare of the residents of the city g hold harmless agreement notwithstanding any other provision of this section the city shall not have responsibility to enter and remove eventgenerated debris from private property until it has obtained the right to enter said property by the private property owner 1 prior to the city or the citys authorized agent entering private rightsofway or other private property to clear andor remove disastergenerated debris the private property owner shall execute an agreement for disaster debris removal with the city agreeing to indemnify defend and hold the federal government the state of florida and the city and their respective agencies employees officers and agents harmless for claims arising from the citys removal of disastergenerated debris 2 the agreement for disaster debris removal shall also include the ability for the city or private property owner to terminate the agreement for convenience upon sixty 60 days written notice and such other terms that are acceptable to the city manager and approved as to form and legal sufficiency by the city attorney the city manager or designee is authorized to execute the disaster debris removal agreements on behalf of the city h disastergenerated debris from residential property 1 responsibility residential property owners are responsible for the collection and removal of disastergenerated debris from their property except to the extent the city is responsible for removal of disastergenerated debris from private rightsofway as provided in section 2101f above 2 piling requirement as provided in this section the city may remove disastergenerated debris collected from residential property residential property owners desiring the city to remove disastergenerated debris shall collect and locate in piles all disastergenerated debris as required by this section before the citys last pass for removal of disastergenerated debris disastergenerated debris piles put out for removal after the city makes its last pass will not be removed by the city 3 segregation requirement residential property owners must segregate structural debris piles from vegetative debris piles and these piles must be segregated from household waste household waste shall be bagged and placed in garbage cans structural debris and vegetative debris shall not be bagged except that loose vegetative debris may be placed in large plastic bags 4 placement of piles residential property owners shall place disaster debris piles a in front of their residence in the swale area immediately adjacent to the edge of the public or private roadway  and b in such a manner as to allow ingress and egress to all residential properties residential property owners may combine their several piles of segregated disastergenerated debris into larger piles to accomplish this requirement 5 damage to sidewalks or mailboxes the city and its agents shall not be responsible for damage to sidewalks or mailboxes when disastergenerated debris is placed on or adjacent thereto 6 city determination if the city determines that a the residential property owners structural debris vegetative debris andor household waste is commingled or has not been collected in accordance with this section the residential property owner shall have fortyeight 48 hours to properly segregate the disastergenerated debris if the residential property owner fails to properly segregate his or her disastergenerated within fortyeight 48 hours then the residential property owner is required to remove and dispose of the disastergenerated debris at his or her expense  or b any disastergenerated debris from nonresidential property including community property has been commingled with the disastergenerated debris of a residential property owner then the city will not remove the disastergenerated debris and the residential property owner is required to remove the disastergenerated debris piles at his or her expense i disastergenerated debris from nonresidential property 1 commingling the city will not remove disastergenerated debris that has come from or been commingled with disastergenerated debris from a nonresidential property  b landscaped medians or culdesacs in communities with private rightsofway  or c privately owned parks or other privately owned properties that are not residential 2 disposal of all disastergenerated debris nonresidential property owners shall collect reduce remove and otherwise dispose of all disastergenerated debris on their property within sixty 60 days of the end of the disaster 3 prohibition of commingling nonresidential property owners shall not a move disastergenerated debris from their property to residential property  or b collect their disastergenerated debris and commingle it with a residential property owners disastergenerated debris piles 4 tub grinding operations tub grinding operations or any other operation to reduce disaster debris from nonresidential property must be conducted at least two hundred 200 feet away from residential property 2101 212012   8162017 secs 21022110  reserved article vi repealed and replaced former art vii  21412146 and enacted a new art vii as set out herein the former art vii pertained to similar subject matter for complete derivation see the table at the end of this volume adopted mar 7 201 changed the title of art vii from finance purchasing guidelines to procurement   purpose  generally the purpose of these purchasing regulations is to a provide a uniform means of acquiring goods and services in a manner which protects the interests of taxpayers  b ensures that qualified vendors have access to the municipal market on a fair and equitable basis  c applies to all purchases of the city irrespective of the source of funding  d provides guidelines to user departments the finance department shall serve as the purchasing gateway to provide assistance and technical expertise in purchasing procedures and to ascertain that user departments understand and comply with established budgetary purchasing and accounting procedures for overall internal control no city employee shall order goods or services without the required authorization funding and purchasingfinance documents exh a 1252007   4182012  exh a 372018   delegated authority the city manager shall appoint the purchasing director or designee as the authority to implement the provisions of this article the purchasing director or designee shall be responsible for the procurement of goods and services governed by this exh a 372018   micro purchases less than two thousand five hundred dollars department heads have authorization to purchase goods and services which are less than two thousand five hundred dollars $250000 for a single purchase subject to a valid current appropriation for the items to be purchased payment for the goods and services shall be made using a purchase order procurement card or a check request form unless the item is a capital asset all purchases of capital assets require a purchase order the procurement requirements shall not be artificially divided so as to constitute a micro purchase exh a 1252007  21411 4182012  exh a 372018 editors note adopted mar 7 201 added provisions to be designated  21411 and renumbered  2141121416 as  2141221427   small purchases of two thousand five hundred dollars and less than five thousand dollars in addition to the requirements in section 21412 purchases of two thousand five hundred dollars $250000 and less than five thousand dollars $500000 must have sought minimum of three 3 verbal quotes and written authorization to the purchasing director or designee in the form of a purchase requisition documentation of the phone number and the name of the person who gave the quote or a memorandum that a quote was sought must be provided with the purchase requisition the procurement requirements shall not be artificially divided so as to constitute a small purchase award shall be made to the lowest responsive and responsible bidder exh a 1252007  21412 4182012   5202015  exh a
